educational_objective: Evaluate for hypersecretion in a pituitary incidentaloma.
question_text: A 24-year-old woman is evaluated for an incidental finding of an enlarged pituitary gland. It was discovered on a recent CT scan of the head performed in the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. She reports no headaches or vision changes. She is having regular periods. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no medications.Physical examination findings, including vital signs, are normal. BMI is 24. There are no striae.Laboratory studies:8 am cortisol 18 μg/dL (497 nmol/L)Prolactin18 ng/mL (18 μg/L)Thyroid-stimulating hormone4.5 μU/mL (4.5 mU/L)Free thyroxine1.8 ng/dL (23 pmol/L)Dedicated pituitary MRI reveals a 9-mm pituitary adenoma. There is no mass effect on the optic chiasm.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test to perform next?

options.text: Measure serum follicle-stimulating hormone and estradiol levels

critique: The most appropriate diagnostic test to perform next is measurement of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) (Option A). Pituitary hypersecretion should be ruled out in all incidentally found pituitary adenomas by measuring serum prolactin and IGF-1 levels. Small growth hormone–secreting pituitary adenomas may not be overtly symptomatic, but diagnosing a growth hormone–secreting tumor when it is smaller than 1 cm in size significantly increases the chance of a surgical cure. Additionally, screening for hypopituitarism is recommended in all pituitary tumors, regardless of symptoms, by measuring serum follicle-stimulating hormone, luteinizing hormone, 8 am cortisol, thyroid-stimulating hormone, free thyroxine, and, in men, 8 am total testosterone levels. In premenopausal women, a menstrual history can assess for hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Abnormal baseline testing may prompt further stimulatory testing to confirm hypopituitarism (Table: Dynamic Testing for Pituitary Dysfunction). Microadenomas (<1 cm) should be reassessed with imaging in 1 year and then every 1 to 2 years thereafter for at least 3 years. Repeat evaluation of pituitary function is unnecessary in microadenomas if initial testing is normal and no change has occurred clinically or radiologically. This patient has a 9-mm pituitary adenoma and has been appropriately tested for prolactin hypersecretion as well as hypopituitarism; an IGF-1 level should also be measured.Measuring serum follicle-stimulating hormone and estradiol levels (Option B) in women with normal periods, such as this patient, is not necessary as menses itself sufficiently rules out hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.Measuring a 24-hour urine free cortisol level (Option C) is not necessary in a patient without clinical signs and symptoms of Cushing syndrome, such as violaceous striae, easy bruising, facial plethora, and dorsocervical and supraclavicular fat pads. This patient has no signs of Cushing syndrome on physical examination.Obtaining a visual field examination (Option D) is important in patients with macroadenomas (tumors ≥1 cm) to obtain a baseline and is required in tumors that cause mass effect on the optic chiasm. Although performing visual field testing in a larger microadenoma for a baseline may be reasonable, it would not be the immediate next step for this asymptomatic patient with a subcentimeter adenoma without evidence of mass effect.
key_points: Pituitary hypersecretion should be ruled out in all incidentally found pituitary adenomas by measuring serum prolactin and insulin-like growth factor-1 levels; diagnosing a growth hormone–secreting tumor when it is smaller than 1 cm in size significantly increases the chance of a surgical cure.
references: Langlois F, Fleseriu M. What to do with incidentally discovered pituitary abnormalities? Med Clin North Am. 2021;105:1081-1098. PMID: 34688416 doi:10.1016/j.mcna.2021.05.015

tables.title: Dynamic Testing for Pituitary Dysfunction
footnotes: ACTH = adrenocorticotropic hormone; AVP = arginine vasopressin; DI = diabetes insipidus; GH = growth hormone; IM = intramuscular; IV = intravenous.
<sup>a</sup>Plasma copeptin measurements after 3% saline can also be used to diagnose arginine vasopressin deficiency, although this method is not yet widely available.

from_critique.statement: The most appropriate diagnostic test to perform next is measurement of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1).
Pituitary hypersecretion should be ruled out in all incidentally found pituitary adenomas by measuring serum prolactin levels.
Pituitary hypersecretion should be ruled out in all incidentally found pituitary adenomas by measuring insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) levels.
Small growth hormone–secreting pituitary adenomas may not be overtly symptomatic.
Diagnosing a growth hormone–secreting tumor when it is smaller than 1 cm in size significantly increases the chance of a surgical cure.
from_critique.extra_field: Diagnosing a growth hormone–secreting tumor when it is smaller than 1 cm in size significantly increases the chance of a surgical cure.

from_critique.statement: Screening for hypopituitarism is recommended in all pituitary tumors, regardless of symptoms.
Screening for hypopituitarism is recommended by measuring serum follicle-stimulating hormone.
Screening for hypopituitarism is recommended by measuring serum luteinizing hormone.
Screening for hypopituitarism is recommended by measuring 8 am cortisol.
Screening for hypopituitarism is recommended by measuring thyroid-stimulating hormone.
Screening for hypopituitarism is recommended by measuring free thyroxine.
Screening for hypopituitarism is recommended in men by measuring 8 am total testosterone levels.
In premenopausal women, a menstrual history can assess for hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.
Abnormal baseline testing may prompt further stimulatory testing to confirm hypopituitarism.
Microadenomas smaller than 1 cm should be reassessed with imaging in 1 year.
Microadenomas smaller than 1 cm should be reassessed with imaging every 1 to 2 years thereafter for at least 3 years.
Repeat evaluation of pituitary function is unnecessary in microadenomas if initial testing is normal and no change has occurred clinically.
Repeat evaluation of pituitary function is unnecessary in microadenomas if initial testing is normal and no change has occurred radiologically.
Measuring serum follicle-stimulating hormone and estradiol levels in women with normal periods is not necessary.
from_critique.extra_field: Menses itself sufficiently rules out hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

from_critique.statement: Menses itself sufficiently rules out hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.
Measuring a 24-hour urine free cortisol level is not necessary in a patient without clinical signs and symptoms of Cushing syndrome.
from_critique.extra_field: Clinical signs and symptoms of Cushing syndrome include violaceous striae, easy bruising, facial plethora, and dorsocervical and supraclavicular fat pads.
cloze_candidates: clinical signs and symptoms of Cushing syndrome

from_critique.statement: Clinical signs and symptoms of Cushing syndrome include violaceous striae.
cloze_candidates: Clinical signs and symptoms of Cushing syndrome

from_critique.statement: Clinical signs and symptoms of Cushing syndrome include easy bruising.
cloze_candidates: Clinical signs and symptoms of Cushing syndrome

from_critique.statement: Clinical signs and symptoms of Cushing syndrome include facial plethora.
cloze_candidates: Clinical signs and symptoms of Cushing syndrome

from_critique.statement: Clinical signs and symptoms of Cushing syndrome include dorsocervical fat pads.
cloze_candidates: Clinical signs and symptoms of Cushing syndrome

from_critique.statement: Clinical signs and symptoms of Cushing syndrome include supraclavicular fat pads.
cloze_candidates: Clinical signs and symptoms of Cushing syndrome

from_critique.statement: Obtaining a visual field examination is important in patients with macroadenomas (tumors 1 cm or larger) to obtain a baseline.
Obtaining a visual field examination is required in tumors that cause mass effect on the optic chiasm.
cloze_candidates: mass effect on the optic chiasm

from_critique.statement: Performing visual field testing in a larger microadenoma for a baseline may be reasonable.

from_key_points.statement: Pituitary hypersecretion should be ruled out in all incidentally found pituitary adenomas by measuring serum prolactin and insulin-like growth factor-1 levels.
Diagnosing a growth hormone–secreting tumor when it is smaller than 1 cm in size significantly increases the chance of a surgical cure.

statements.statement: In the ACTH stimulation test for ACTH (cortisol) deficiency, a peak serum cortisol level > 18 micrograms per deciliter (496.8 nanomoles per liter) indicates a normal response.
cloze_candidates: peak serum cortisol level greater than 18 micrograms per deciliter (496.8 nanomoles per liter)

statements.statement: In the ACTH stimulation test, a lower peak serum cortisol threshold of 14 to 15 micrograms per deciliter (390-414 nanomoles per liter) is sufficient when using newer, more specific immunoassays for measuring cortisol.
cloze_candidates: lower peak serum cortisol threshold of 14 to 15 micrograms per deciliter (390-414 nanomoles per liter)

statements.statement: In the water deprivation test, urine osmolality > 800 milliosmoles per kilogram H2O is a normal response to water deprivation, indicating that vasopressin production and peripheral effect are intact and the diagnosis is most likely primary polydipsia.
cloze_candidates: urine osmolality greater than 800 milliosmoles per kilogram H2O

statements.statement: In the water deprivation test, urine osmolality between 300 and 800 milliosmoles per kilogram H2O suggests partial AVP disorder.
cloze_candidates: urine osmolality between 300 and 800 milliosmoles per kilogram H2O

statements.statement: In the water deprivation test, urine osmolality < 300 milliosmoles per kilogram H2O is consistent with AVP disorder.
cloze_candidates: urine osmolality less than 300 milliosmoles per kilogram H2O

statements.statement: In the desmopressin challenge, an increase in urine osmolality by > 50% after desmopressin is consistent with complete AVP deficiency (central DI) when urine osmolality is < 300 milliosmoles per kilogram H2O before the challenge.
cloze_candidates: increase in urine osmolality by greater than 50%
urine osmolality is less than 300 milliosmoles per kilogram H2O

statements.statement: In the desmopressin challenge, an increase in urine osmolality by < 50% after desmopressin indicates complete AVP resistance (nephrogenic DI) when urine osmolality is < 300 milliosmoles per kilogram H2O before the challenge.
cloze_candidates: increase in urine osmolality by less than 50%
urine osmolality is less than 300 milliosmoles per kilogram H2O

statements.statement: In the glucose tolerance test for GH excess (acromegaly), a GH nadir of 1.0 nanograms per milliliter or higher (or 0.4 nanograms per milliliter or higher on an ultrasensitive assay) is diagnostic of acromegaly.
cloze_candidates: GH nadir of 1.0 nanograms per milliliter or higher

sentences.text: The most appropriate diagnostic test to perform next is measurement of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) (Option A).
Pituitary hypersecretion should be ruled out in all incidentally found pituitary adenomas by measuring serum prolactin and IGF-1 levels.

Small growth hormone–secreting pituitary adenomas may not be overtly symptomatic, but diagnosing a growth hormone–secreting tumor when it is smaller than 1 cm in size significantly increases the chance of a surgical cure.

Additionally, screening for hypopituitarism is recommended in all pituitary tumors, regardless of symptoms, by measuring serum follicle-stimulating hormone, luteinizing hormone, 8 am cortisol, thyroid-stimulating hormone, free thyroxine, and, in men, 8 am total testosterone levels.
In premenopausal women, a menstrual history can assess for hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.
Abnormal baseline testing may prompt further stimulatory testing to confirm hypopituitarism (Table: Dynamic Testing for Pituitary Dysfunction).
Microadenomas (<1 cm) should be reassessed with imaging in 1 year and then every 1 to 2 years thereafter for at least 3 years.
Repeat evaluation of pituitary function is unnecessary in microadenomas if initial testing is normal and no change has occurred clinically or radiologically.
This patient has a 9-mm pituitary adenoma and has been appropriately tested for prolactin hypersecretion as well as hypopituitarism; an IGF-1 level should also be measured.

Measuring serum follicle-stimulating hormone and estradiol levels (Option B) in women with normal periods, such as this patient, is not necessary as menses itself sufficiently rules out hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

Measuring a 24-hour urine free cortisol level (Option C) is not necessary in a patient without clinical signs and symptoms of Cushing syndrome, such as violaceous striae, easy bruising, facial plethora, and dorsocervical and supraclavicular fat pads.
This patient has no signs of Cushing syndrome on physical examination.
Obtaining a visual field examination (Option D) is important in patients with macroadenomas (tumors ≥1 cm) to obtain a baseline and is required in tumors that cause mass effect on the optic chiasm.

Although performing visual field testing in a larger microadenoma for a baseline may be reasonable, it would not be the immediate next step for this asymptomatic patient with a subcentimeter adenoma without evidence of mass effect.

Pituitary hypersecretion should be ruled out in all incidentally found pituitary adenomas by measuring serum prolactin and insulin-like growth factor-1 levels; diagnosing a growth hormone–secreting tumor when it is smaller than 1 cm in size significantly increases the chance of a surgical cure.
